explosives.rationale: Containing no atom groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: The flashing point is -20degC (ICSC, 2002) (closed cup flash test) and the boiling point is 43degC which is classified into Category 2. Classified into Class 3 and Category 6.1 (UN#1259) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no atom groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified into Class 3 and Category 6.1 (UN#1259) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine and chlorine

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to gaseous substances are not available - boiling point: 43degC (ICSC,2002), test temperature: 55degC

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on the rat LC50 (4 hours) value of 12ppm, calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of vapour) of 35ppm (0.5 hours), was lower than 90% of the saturated vapor concentration (528,000ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 400mmHg (25.8degC) (equivalent to 53,300Pa at 25.8degC) (HSDB, 2005), the substance was considered as "vapour containing substantially no mist" and was classified based on standard values expressed in ppm.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the following human evidence found in EHC 108 (1991): "Primary skin irritation reactions to nickel salts in solution were observed when human volunteers were patch tested. When aqueous solutions of nickel chloride were applied to the back, the threshold concentrations for irritancy were 1% with occlusion and 10% without occlusion."

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the following human evidence found in HSDB, 2005: "Vapor is irritating to eyes, nose, and throat. Liquid will burn the skin and eyes", which should be considered as "irreversible damage to eyes" from the viewpoint of safety.

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause allergy or asthma symptoms or breathing difficulties if inhaled
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Based on the following epidemiological observation provided by EHC 108 (1991): "A chemical engineer, who had been exposed for a long period to low levels of nickel carbonyl, developed asthma and Lffler's syndrome. In addition to pulmonary infiltrations and eosinophilia, which are markers in Lffler's syndrome, the patient had an eczematous dermatitis of the hands."

carcinogenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on heritable mutagenicity tests, germ/somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and in vitro mutagenicity tests and positive data on somatic cell genotoxicity tests in vivo (DNA binding tests), described in EHC 108 (1991) and IARC 49 (1990).

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Group 1 (as nickel compounds) by IARC(1990)and Category K by NTP (2005).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence of malformations (anophthalmia, microphthalmia, cystic lung, hydronephrosis, exencephalia, fused ribs and cleft palate), and hemorrhage in the chorionic cavity in teratogenicity tests on rats and guinea pigs, described in IARC 49 (1990) and EHC 108 (1990), and the absence of description of the effects on parent animals.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (central nervous system, liver, respiratory system, kidney, adrenal gland, heart, spleen, pancreas)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (central nervous system, liver, respiratory system, kidney, adrenal gland, heart, spleen, pancreas)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "frontal headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, insomnia, irritation followed by pulmonary symptoms" and "parenchymatous degeneration in the liver, kidneys, adrenal and spleen, cerebral edema and dot hemorrhage in the brain" (EHC 108, 1991) and the evidence from animal studies including "interstitial pneumonitis associated with focal atelectasis and necrosis, parenchymatous degeneration associated with focal necrosis in the liver, spleen, kidneys and pancreas" and "inflammation, atelectasis and interstitial fibroplasia in the lungs; congestion and hemorrhage in the kidney and adrenal" (CICAD 61, 2004). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
